sn42.2:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn42.2:1.2: Then Tāḷapuṭa the dancing master came up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
sn42.2:1.3: “Sir, I have heard that the dancers of the past who were teachers of teachers said:
sn42.2:1.4: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’
sn42.2:1.5: What does the Buddha say about this?”
sn42.2:1.6: “Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”
sn42.2:1.12: And for a third time Tāḷapuṭa said to the Buddha:
sn42.2:1.13: “Sir, I have heard that the dancers of the past who were teachers of teachers said:
sn42.2:1.14: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’
sn42.2:1.15: What does the Buddha say about this?”
sn42.2:2.1: “Clearly, chief, I’m not getting through to you when I say:
sn42.2:2.5: When sentient beings are still not free of greed, and are still bound by greed,
sn42.2:2.6: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more arousing things.
sn42.2:2.7: When sentient beings are still not free of hate, and are still bound by hate,
sn42.2:2.8: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more hateful things.
sn42.2:2.9: When sentient beings are still not free of delusion, and are still bound by delusion,
sn42.2:2.10: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more delusory things.
sn42.2:2.11: And so, being heedless and negligent themselves, they’ve encouraged others to be heedless and negligent. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the hell called ‘Laughter’.
sn42.2:2.12: But if you have such a view:
sn42.2:2.13: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’ This is your wrong view.
sn42.2:2.14: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:
sn42.2:3.1: When he said this, Tāḷapuṭa cried and burst out in tears.
sn42.2:3.2: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:
sn42.2:3.3: ‘Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”
sn42.2:3.4: “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.
sn42.2:3.5: But sir, for a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by the dancers of the past who were teachers of teachers, who said:
sn42.2:3.6: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’
sn42.2:3.8: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn42.2:3.9: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn42.2:3.10: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
sn42.2:3.11: And the dancing master Tāḷapuṭa received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
